etymologies: early 16th century: from French flux (formerly flus), from Latin fluxus ‘a flow’(see flux: the use in cards can be compared with English run)

definitions: (in poker) a hand of cards all of the same suit.
shortDefinitions: (in poker or brag) hand of cards all of same suit

etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘move rapidly, spring up’, especially of a bird ‘fly up suddenly’): symbolic, fl- frequently beginning words connected with sudden movement; perhaps influenced by flash and blush

definitions: (of a person's skin, face, etc.) become red and hot, typically as the result of illness or strong emotion

examples.text: Mr. Cunningham flushed angrily

definitions: cause (a person's skin or face) to become red and hot

examples.text: the chill air flushed the parson's cheeks

definitions: glow or cause to glow with warm color or light

examples.text: the sky was flushed with the gold of dawn
the ash in the center of the fire flushed up

shortDefinitions: glow with warm colour or light

definitions: cleanse (something, especially a toilet) by causing large quantities of water to pass through it

examples.text: the nurse flushed out the catheter
flush the toilet

definitions: (of a toilet) be cleansed by flushing

examples.text: Cally heard the toilet flush

shortDefinitions: (of toilet) be cleansed in this way

definitions: remove or dispose of (an object or substance) by flushing

examples.text: I flushed the pills down the toilet
the kidneys require more water to flush out waste products

shortDefinitions: remove or dispose of in this way

definitions: cause (a liquid) to flow through something

examples.text: 0.3 ml of saline is gently flushed through the tube

definitions: drive (a bird, especially a game bird, or an animal) from its cover

examples.text: the grouse were flushed from the woods

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

definitions: cause to be revealed; force into the open

examples.text: they're trying to flush Tilton out of hiding

definitions: (of a plant) send out fresh shoots

examples.text: the plant had started to flush by late March

definitions: a reddening of the face, skin, etc., typically caused by illness or strong emotion

examples.text: a flush of embarrassment rose to her cheeks

definitions: an area of warm color or light

examples.text: the bird has a pinkish flush on the breast

shortDefinitions: area of warm colour or light

definitions: a sudden rush of intense emotion

examples.text: I was carried away in a flush of enthusiasm

definitions: a period when something is new or particularly fresh and vigorous

examples.text: he is no longer in the first flush of youth

shortDefinitions: period of great freshness and vigour

definitions: a sudden abundance or spate of something

examples.text: the frogs feast on the great flush of insects

definitions: a fresh growth of leaves, flowers, or fruit.
an act of cleansing something, especially a toilet, with a sudden flow of water

examples.text: an old-fashioned toilet uses six or seven gallons per flush
leave the hose running to give the system a good flush out

definitions: the device used for producing a flow of water in a toilet

examples.text: he pressed the flush absentmindedly

shortDefinitions: device used for producing flow of water in toilet

definitions: denoting a type of toilet that has a flush device

examples.text: a flush toilet

definitions: a sudden flow

examples.text: the melting snow provides a flush of water

definitions: the action of driving a game bird from its cover

examples.text: the dogs retrieve the birds after the flush

shortDefinitions: action of driving game bird from cover

etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘perfect, lacking nothing’): probably related to flush

definitions: completely level or even with another surface

examples.text: the gates are flush with the adjoining fencing

definitions: (of printed text) not indented or protruding

examples.text: each line is flush with the left-hand margin

definitions: (of a door) having a smooth surface, without indented or protruding panels or moldings.
shortDefinitions: (of door) having smooth surface without indented panels etc.

definitions: having plenty of something, especially money

examples.text: the banks are flush with funds

definitions: (of money) plentiful

examples.text: the years when cash was flush

definitions: so as to be level or even

examples.text: the screw must fit flush with the surface

shortDefinitions: so as to be level or even

definitions: so as to be directly centered; squarely

examples.text: Jumbo reached up and hit Bruno flush on the jaw

definitions: fill in (a joint) level with a surface.
shortDefinitions: fill in joint level with surface

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘marshy place’): variant of flash

definitions: a piece of wet ground over which water flows without being confined to a definite channel.
shortDefinitions: piece of wet ground over which water flows without being confined to definite channel
